issue.title: Update Classic McEliece
issue.body:
Fixes #1314 and takes into account discussion from #1459. 

Changes SPDX line for `src\common\pqclean_shims\crypto_declassify.h` from MIT to CC0.

<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [Yes] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [No] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

issue.title: Enabling signing of arbitrary data
issue.body:
<!--
Thank you for your pull request. Please review these requirements:

Contributors guide: https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING

Other than that, provide a description above this comment if there isn't one already

If this fixes a github issue, make sure to have a line saying 'Fixes #XXXX' (without quotes) in the commit message.
-->

This patch provides two different different changes:
- (bb172fb) Enables the use of a EVP_md_null together with NULL in OQS/PQC pkey meth for setting the digest via the CTRL interface
- (fc7ab7d) Enables the use of EVP_PKEY_sign() and EVP_PKEY_verify() with OQS/PQC algorithms by porting the code from the pkey_oqs digestsign() and pkey_oqs_digestverify() into pkey_sign() and pkey_verify() of the pkey meth.

##### Checklist
<!-- Remove items that do not apply. For completed items, change [ ] to [x]. -->
- [ ] documentation is added or updated
- [ ] tests are added or updated

comment.body: The OpenSSL project has indicated that OpenSSL 1.1.1 will reach end-of-life in September 2023.  As such, we are discontinuing development on OQS-OpenSSL 1.1.1, and recommend all users switch to OpenSSL 3 and the [OQS Provider for OpenSSL 3](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/), which provides all the same functionality that OQS-OpenSSL 1.1.1 does.  Hence we are closing open pull requests and issues in OQS-OpenSSL 1.1.1 as won't-fix.

issue.title: Hybrid key exchange with x25519

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issue.body: Do we have support for hybrid key exchange with x25519?  Looking at https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/oqs-template/generate.yml#L75, for example, we list a NID for x25519+kyber512 in the configuration file, but then searching the generated code in the `ssl` directory or in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/qsc.h, I don't see any reference to x25519 with Kyber or the specific NID in question.  @baentsch any idea?

issue.title: Make OID's settable (?)

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issue.body:
As per the discussion [here](https://github.com/IETF-Hackathon/pqc-certificates/issues/3#issuecomment-1325652216) it may be advisable to add to oqs-openssl111 the ability to set OIDs dynamically to integrate it into interoperability testing setups. For reference, [oqs-provider already has this capability](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/main/ALGORITHMS.md#oids).

General question: Do we want oqs-openssl111 participate in interop testing? If no, this issue can be closed as "wontfix".

issue.title: Gracefully handle algorithm enablement

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issue.body:
As soon as https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/1331 lands, tests for algorithms disabled in oqs-openssl would fail if only an algorithm subset is enabled, e.g., STD. This issue is to collect options how to handle this: 
Initial ideas:
1) Don't care, i.e., do not support/perform (CI) testing with "standard-only" algorithm selections.
2) Create a possibly convoluted script to filter algorithms under test in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/oqs-test/common.py using information from "oqsconfig.h" (un-set #defines).
3) Add code throughout oqs-openssl to explicitly permit unavailability of an algorithm, possibly guarded by an environment variable "OQS_TEST_ONLY".

Preferences? Further alternatives? @xvzcf @dstebila @christianpaquin ?

Options 1 (not testing what is actually deployed) and 3 (possibly extensive code changes for test-only behaviour changes) have such undesirable consequences that I personally think 2 ought to be implemented. But I'm all ears for alternatives.

comment.body: The OpenSSL project has indicated that OpenSSL 1.1.1 will reach end-of-life in September 2023.  As such, we are discontinuing development on OQS-OpenSSL 1.1.1, and recommend all users switch to OpenSSL 3 and the [OQS Provider for OpenSSL 3](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/), which provides all the same functionality that OQS-OpenSSL 1.1.1 does.  Hence we are closing open pull requests and issues in OQS-OpenSSL 1.1.1 as won't-fix.

issue.title: make install_dev attempts to install oqs headers that are not part of the source tree
issue.body:
File: Configurations/unix-Makefile.tmpl
Line 617-623
Branch: https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/Configurations/unix-Makefile.tmpl

Those line cause `make install_dev` fail, because oqs directory is not part of the source tree. The headers are part of liboqs and, by the time the make command is executed, are already installed.

comment.body: The OpenSSL project has indicated that OpenSSL 1.1.1 will reach end-of-life in September 2023. issue.title: Add Dockerized Environment for Improved Installation and Usage Experience
issue.body:
<!--
Thank you for your pull request. Please review these requirements:

Contributors guide: https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING

Other than that, provide a description above this comment if there isn't one already

If this fixes a github issue, make sure to have a line saying 'Fixes #XXXX' (without quotes) in the commit message.
-->

This PR addresses the challenges faced by users during the installation process by introducing a Dockerized environment for the project. The aim is to provide a consistent and reliable setup that mitigates issues arising from differences in user environments.The installation process of the project in local can encounter various difficulties due to differences in operating systems, dependencies, and configurations across users' environments. These discrepancies could lead to be challenging for users to get the project up and running smoothly.

The PR includes the following changes:

* Added a Dockerfile that builds the project's environment based on the Python 3.9 Alpine image. It installs the required dependencies. The Dockerfile also sets the working directory and clones the necessary repositories (openssl and liboqs), compiling and installing them.

* Created a docker-compose.yml file that defines the services and volumes for the Docker container. The shared volume is configured to link the host and the container, ensuring that generated files are accessible outside the container.

* Instruction for OpenSSL commands on the Docker container.

These changes provide users with an easy and reproducible way to set up and run the project in a Docker environment. The Dockerized environment ensures consistent execution and simplifies the installation process.

##### Checklist
<!-- Remove items that do not apply. For completed items, change [ ] to [x]. -->
- [x ] documentation is added or updated

comment.body: The OpenSSL project has indicated that OpenSSL 1.1.1 will reach end-of-life in September 2023.  As such, we are discontinuing development on OQS-OpenSSL 1.1.1, and recommend all users switch to OpenSSL 3 and the [OQS Provider for OpenSSL 3](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/), which provides all the same functionality that OQS-OpenSSL 1.1.1 does.  Hence we are closing open pull requests and issues in OQS-OpenSSL 1.1.1 as won't-fix.

issue.title: Programmatically load provider
issue.body:
Hi all, I was able to compile libqos and oqsprovider under windows, so I end up with oqsprovider.dll
I'm trying to integrate dll in my c++ code loading dll in some way as I do for "legacy" and "default" (even if that providers are not dll in my scenario)
`OSSL_PROVIDER_try_load(NULL, "oqsprovider", 1);`
but I can't load it. Do you have some advice for me on how can programmatically load provider?
thanks

comment.body: @micheleselea FYI, here's (two) proposals how to force use of specific PQC/QSC KEMs: https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/main/USAGE.md#selecting-tls13-default-groups. A third obviously is use of the [OpenSSL API](https://www.openssl.org/docs/man3.0/man3/SSL_CTX_set1_groups.html).

I read that the best interaction between oqs and OpenSSL should be using 3.2 and I wanna make a try. Do you know if there's a scheduled release date for 3.2 alfa or beta?

I'm trying to integrate dll in my c++ code loading dll in some way as I do for "legacy" and "default" (even if that providers are not dll in my scenario)
`OSSL_PROVIDER_try_load(NULL, "oqsprovider", 1);`

thanks

comment.body:
> Do you know if there's a scheduled release date for 3.2 alfa or beta?

No. That's probably best asked [upstream](https://github.com/openssl/openssl/issues). IMO highly unlikely that that's going to be still 2023 given that 3.1.0 only came out a few months ago.

issue.title: CC0 license is an obstacle
issue.body:
Dear colleagues, 

we are planning to package liboqs for Fedora. We build liboqs with `-DOQS_ALGS_ENABLED=STD` to minimize support of non-standardized algorithms.

We found that the folders
```
./src/kem/kyber/pqclean_kyber*_aarch64
./src/sig/dilithium/pqclean_dilithium*_aarch64
./src/sig/sphincs/pqclean_sphincs*
```
contain CC0 license which is not acceptable for Fedora by default (and AFAIU, other Linux distributions).

I believe that for aarch64 we could fallback to a generic (slower) implementation in the compile time, but it's obviously not the best possible option.

Is it possible to get in contact with the authors of these implementation to get an agreement about double-licensing of these implementations? MIT, Apache2 or smth else is fine for our purpose.

Many thanks in advance!

comment.body: Yes, this looks viable. Many thanks!
